title: UK small business owners are not confident about their future
text:
Small business owners in the UK are feeling the pressure of continuing political uncertainty and rising costs, according to the latest survey findings from the Federation of Small Businesses.

Almost two thirds of the 1,200 business owners who took part in the survey said they did not expect their firm's performance to improve over the next three months, while 44 per cent - a five-year high - said they expected theirs to worsen.

The sector has called for the Government to secure a Brexit deal and come forward with 'radical policy interventions to arrest a dogged lack of confidence' among business owners.

The small business index, which measures confidence within the industry, has delivered a negative reading for five consecutive months - a first in its history. The measure stands at -8.1 in Q3 2019, down more than six points compared to the same period last year.

Long-term planning for small businesses was hit in the last survey: Exports and investment plans both dropped, while hiring intentions also fell

Meanwhile, small business owners continue to put investment plans on hold with only one in four planning to increase theirs this quarter – the lowest proportion in five years.

Some 14 per cent of survey respondents are planning to actively decrease investment, up two percentage points compared to this time last year.

But it is firms that do business internationally that have been hit the hardest by uncertainty caused by the current political and economic landscape.

Only 25 per cent of small business owners reported an increase in exports over the past three months, the lowest proportion in five years.

Long-term planning in general was hit as in addition to the impact on exports and investment, hiring intentions also plummeted.

However, fewer than one in seven (13 per cent) small employers is planning to take on additional staff in the next three months, the lowest proportion since Q4 2017.

Mike Cherry, chairman of the FSB, said: 'These findings must serve as an urgent wake-up call for policymakers. Even in the aftermath of the financial crash, we didn't see such a sustained string of negative confidence readings. Three years of political uncertainty and rising costs have stifled output and left small firms unable to plan, invest and grow.

'There's a real sense of exasperation among small firms. Big decisions – whether that be taking on new staff, purchasing machinery or embarking on sales in a new country – are being put on hold because we have no idea what our trading environment will look like in less than four weeks' time.

'And what's worse, two thirds of those who would be negatively impacted by a no-deal scenario say they can't prepare for it.'

Cherry explained we are now in the final chance period for getting a Brexit deal and that the Government must seize this final opportunity.

Mike Cherry, chairman of the FSB said the Government must seize the final chance for a getting a Brexit deal

Budget should aim to reverse uncertainty

Cherry called on the Chancellor to come forward with an ambitious Budget aimed at reversing the impacts of uncertainty.

'He must throw lifelines to the small exporters that are especially hamstrung,' he added. 'Direct financial assistance – such as £3,000 Brexit vouchers – to enable access to expertise and support would mark a much-needed step forward.'

Meanwhile almost all small business owners - 93 per cent - said operating costs were either stable or rising while two thirds say costs have risen over the past 12 months.

The most frequently cited causes of this increase are labour, flagged by 40 per cent of firms, as well as inputs at 31 per cent, utilities at 29 per cent, fuel at 24 per cent and regulation 23 per cent.

Cherry added: 'The Chancellor must compile a Budget which alleviates the impacts of rising operating costs, rather than simply adds to them. That means uprating the £3,000 discount on national insurance bills for small employers offered through the employment allowance and reintroducing a statutory sick pay rebate.

'Support with the costs of transport – especially fuel – and business rates would also help to reinject some optimism into a small business community that's been held back by uncertainty for years now.

'Sole traders are also crying out for support in this unpredictable climate. Now is not the time to blindly push on with IR35 changes billed for April.'
description: The Federation of Small Businesses has revealed confidence in the sector has been at its longest low, for nine years, while half of small business owners expect poor near-term performance.
